title-group.article-title: The Sayings Clusters in Proverbs: Towards an Associative Reading Strategy

abstract.p: Some scholars argue that every proverb should be interpreted on its own, while others search for clusters of sayings and posit that such clusters should determine how one understands a proverb. The first half of this study argues that the solution lies somewhere in between: clusters are important for interpreting individual proverbs, but they do not completely fix the meaning of a saying. Instead, they allow for several possible meanings, and they invite the reader to construct creatively his/her own reading. The second half of this article seeks to demonstrate how this theory works in practice, by using the example of the first three verses of Proverbs 16. In accordance with the reading strategy advocated in this study, several possible readings of the section are proposed.

sec.title: 1. Does Context Matter?
sec.p: Some scholars argue that each saying in Proverbs 10–29 stands on its own and that a proverb's context should not influence its interpretation.1 McKane, for example, insists,

disp-quote.p: [T]here is, for the most part, no context in the sentence literature … the individual wisdom sentence is a complete entity… I admit that there are editorial principles of different kinds according to which sentences are grouped. I shall call attention to some of these, while maintaining that they have a secondary character and do not contradict the statement that there is, for the most part, no context in the sentence literature.2

sec.p: Westermann expresses a similar opinion in writing about the first few verses of Proverbs 16, the section I will investigate shortly:

disp-quote.p: Also possible is the intention of the compiler to place a group of Yahweh sayings in the middle of the larger collection of 10:1-22:16. Such compiling, at any rate, is a redactive procedure; it mirrors the compiler's intention. It has nothing to do with the original development of individual proverbs; nothing alters the fact that, to begin with, each saying is an independent unit in and of itself. This is confirmed when we consider each individual Yahweh saying on its own merit. All of these are extremely diverse and, within the general grouping of Yahweh sayings, belong to different categories.3

sec.p: McKane and Westermann, among others, are certainly right when they argue that most, if not all, proverbs were probably born as individual sayings. However, many questions can be raised concerning this approach. Not denying the fascinating contribution of approaches that search for the oldest textual layers, an important question concerns why the reader should downplay the ‘secondary’ (McKane) or ‘redactive’ (Westermann) editorial activity of a compiler in his/her interpretation. After all, if someone finds in a book a sentence which was previously used in a different context, he/she would still like to understand that sentence in the book which is in his/her hands. In other words, the reader may have a legitimate, essential interest in the ‘secondary’ re-use of the sentence, and not its ‘original’ meaning. Undoubtedly, many sayings in Proverbs 10–29 had a long history during which they were used in diverse contexts, perhaps even with different meanings. However, we can only imagine in what other literary contexts and life situations they might have been used, while we do have certain knowledge about this particular context of Proverbs’ present form. Why should we ignore this known context if it colours the interpretation of a particular sentence in an interesting way? Furthermore, as the whole is often more than the sum of the parts, perhaps it is worth investigating whole sections of proverbs to see if the results of editorial activities enable us to construe a richer interpretation of some sayings than if we took them only on their own.

Such concerns would be welcomed by many scholars at the other end of the spectrum of scholarly opinions who contend that there are many carefully construed clusters of sayings in Proverbs 10–29, and that these chains of proverbs unambiguously drive home one single point. They argue that these clusters control the meaning of individual sayings and, consequently, that a saying, if it is a member of such a cluster, cannot properly be understood without considering its context.4 However, just as neglecting a proverb's literary context seems to be a problematic approach, this kind of emphasis on clusters is not without its own problems either. If it was the aim of the editors of Proverbs to present well-construed thematic sections—sections which convey a well described, clear message—then those editors did not choose the best medium for delivering it. The meaning of individual proverbs is often ambiguous, and it seems to be a rather challenging task to present a single point unambiguously through putting such ambiguous sayings next to each other.5 Furthermore, in order to reach the ‘right’ interpretation of a cluster, interpreters often have to create a very broad definition of that cluster's ‘theme’, along with having to skip over some verses, amend others, suggest unusual meanings to otherwise well attested words, establish logical connections between verses which are far from obvious for most readers, and so on. These gymnastic interpretative techniques undermine the credibility of the theory that clusters convey clearly defined teachings, and that understanding a cluster is a prerequisite for understanding a proverb.6

However, to say that there are no strict thematic units with detailed, unambiguous messages does not mean that we cannot find clusters of sayings.7 Weeks found 58 per cent of the verses in Prov. 10.1–22.16 and in Proverbs 25–29 to be linked to their neighbour (Weeks did not investigate Prov. 22.17–24.34 in this respect). This high number makes it likely that there are clusters of sayings in the collection. Yet, as Weeks explains, most of the connections between the verses are not thematic, but rather literary. Verses alliterate, for instance, or they use the same expressions. Even when they are about the same subject, that subject is usually quite broad (e.g. the ‘righteous people’ and all the different issues in connection with them), and only occasionally do consecutive verses discuss the same narrow topic.8

Weeks argues that the varied nature of the linkage between verses suggests that the method the compilers used was usually associative and that they did not try to construct a logical, unambiguous discussion of certain topics in these clusters. Considering this ‘weak’ nature of connection between the sayings, Weeks concludes that ‘the collections are, broadly, atomistic: an understanding of the individual sayings is neither dependent on, nor necessarily enhanced by, a consideration of their place in a collection'.9 Thus, we see in Weeks a similar position to that of Westermann and McKane.10

Knut M. Heim, however, challenges this conclusion, arguing that 58 per cent is surely a high enough number, and that the interpreter should not neglect the fact that the compilers, one way or the other, connected the sayings to each other. Even as most clusters are incapable of providing a precise ‘thematic development’, it is legitimate to try to find the main point that they drive home.11
Heim's argument is persuasive until we learn the results of Michael V. Fox when he checked Weeks's data. In his recent Anchor Bible commentary on Proverbs 10–31 he states,

disp-quote.p: Experimenting with Weeks's methods on several batches of verses taken from different parts of the book and randomly scrambled, I found nearest-neighbor linkages in 36–60 percent of the verses in each batch. A more liberal use of ‘theme’ would have yielded much higher percentages, while an elimination of ‘literal’ links would have reduced them. Weeks also concludes that thematic considerations were not of major importance to the editors (p. 37). This is probably true overall, but when thematic clusters do occur, they are relevant to interpretation.12

sec.p: Fox's investigation shows that 58 per cent might not be as high a number as Heim thought. Thus, based on Weeks's and Fox's investigations, we probably should not expect as many highly developed clusters with a strong connection between the proverbs, as Heim does, especially seeing that the links between verses are predominantly literary or delineate only broad themes. Nevertheless, 58 per cent is high enough to suggest some kind of organization. One should not forget that it is only an average for the whole of 10.1–22.16 and 25.1–29.27, and many sub-sections of the book reach a percentage which goes well beyond the range of 36–60 per cent that Fox got by randomly scrambling the verses.13

At this point it is time to position the approach that I am going to advocate in this wide spectrum of scholarly views. We have seen the range of opinions from ‘every saying stands on its own’ (McKane, Westermann), through ‘there are clusters but their significance is limited’ (Weeks, Fox), to ‘there are a lot of clusters and in most cases an individual saying should be understood according to the clues provided by the cluster in which it occurs’ (Heim, Waltke). The associative approach I will argue for has similarities to the last two options. It accepts the results of Weeks's and Fox's research, yet it seeks to utilize those ‘weak’ clusters for the interpretation of individual proverbs.

On the one hand, I agree with the conclusions of Fox and Weeks that some kind of ‘associative thinking’ explains the existing links between proverbial sayings in our collections.14 As Fox explains the procedure, when ‘an “editor” (or “compiler”) writes down one proverb he knows… [it] makes him think of another one'.15

On the other hand, this conclusion leads me to a method of interpretation which is different from that of either Fox or Weeks. Fox says that ‘thematic clusters’ are relevant for interpretation, which implicitly suggests that non-thematic links are not relevant.16 But even in the case of thematic clusters he is reluctant to go beyond recognizing the overarching broad themes of saying sequences. He does not try to find a detailed, logical message the author/editor/compiler may have wanted to convey through the catchwords, alliterations, and topical similarities in the consecutive verses, as he thinks (probably rightly) that the compiler did not hide such a message there waiting to be discovered. Weeks, as we have seen, also asserts that the understanding of individual sayings is not ‘necessarily enhanced by…a consideration of their place in a collection’, and he even uses the word ‘atomistic’ for describing the nature of the sayings of Proverbs 10–22 and 25–29.17

My conclusion, however, is that the presence of ‘weak connections’ should not lead one to an ‘atomistic’ reading. Quite the contrary, the word ‘association’ suggests that the compilers pondered their proverbs, and sometimes pondered them in sequence. Maybe they reflected on a proverb in light of other proverbs with which they associated it. We cannot know for sure, but this is certainly the effect these clusters have on many readers—an effect exemplified by the many studies trying to construct coherent readings of clusters. Apparently, many who read several sayings about roughly the same topic and/or connected by literary devices almost automatically try to ponder the sayings in the light of each other. Such pondering inevitably leads to attempts to construct a coherent reading of a possible cluster and create logical connections between the ‘originally’ disconnected sayings. It is rather natural to suspect that stimulating such ‘meditation’ on a cluster of sayings was the intention of the compilers in their organization of the sayings—but whatever their intention was, this is one of the strongest effects of the literary compilation, and I do not see why we should resist it.

This approach, of course, leaves much space for the imagination of the reader. The logical connections between different verses and their effects on the interpretation of other verses often can be construed in more than one way. As readers come from different backgrounds with different questions to the text, their contemplations on it will be different.

In other words, my approach is somewhere between that of those who say that the reader has to find the meaning that was envisaged by the author/compiler through the links between the sayings, and that of those who say that each proverb carries its own meaning. Instead of finding the meaning or not searching for such a meaning at all, I suggest the reader constructs such meaning(s). The choice of words is important: there is a difference between ‘finding’ (or reconstructing) and ‘constructing’ a meaning. Furthermore, there is a difference between speaking about ‘the meaning’ and ‘a meaning'. I fully accept that the links between verses in a cluster are often vague enough to leave space for constructing several possible meanings, and I also accept that the reader plays a significant role in constructing meaning. Thus, in most of the cases, one cannot claim that he/she has found the authoritative meaning of the text. Yet I do claim that constructing such readings is not only allowed by the text but is even encouraged by it, and as such it represents an appropriate reading method for Proverbs 10–29.

The fact that such an associative reading does not produce the one and only authoritative reading, but can produce several different readings of the same text, does not mean that it is arbitrary and without control. Differentiating between better and worse readings is still important. Obviously, the reader always has to pay close attention to the exact words of a text (i.e. they cannot read ‘black’ where ‘white’ is written), and the framework of the book (Prov. 1–9 and 30–31) provides a context that restricts the range of possible readings of a cluster of verses. Furthermore, the harmony between the many sayings of Proverbs 10–29 also acts as a control on imaginative readings.18
To conclude, my approach can be summarized in three points:

list-item.p: Clusters enrich our readings of individual sayings because they encourage us to reflect upon sayings in the light of their neighbours. Even if a cluster does not provide a fixed, detailed message, the reader is prompted to construe one on the basis of the cluster.

This does not mean that a cluster has one, single, authoritative meaning in itself, since the logical connections between verses are not defined. An ‘associative approach’ that fills in the logical gaps between the verses can produce many different readings.19
The book as a whole, and especially its framework, provides a context which constrains (to some extent) how the reader can fill in the gaps between the verses in a cluster.

sec.title: 2. An Example: Proverbs 16.1–3
sec.p: As the ‘associative reading’ recommended here requires a close reading of the text, space permits me to discuss only a few verses. I have chosen to investigate the first three verses of a well-known cluster: Prov. 16.1–9.20 Scholarly interpretation of this cluster has deployed all the above-mentioned approaches. Some deny the importance of this cluster for the interpretation of its individual verses (Westermann, McKane).21 Others provide a coherent reading of the whole cluster, thereby suggesting that these verses have one right interpretation (Heim, Waltke).22 Others recognize the overarching theme of the cluster but refuse to go too much into reconstructing logical relationships between the verses (Fox).23 My approach emphasizes the importance of the cluster (contra the first opinion), explicitly recognizes that there are more than one possible reading of it (contra the second opinion), and considers that pondering the possible connections between the verses is important (contra the third opinion).

I will focus on the first three verses in ch. 16, and not only because of the pragmatic reason of limited space. Verses 1–3 can be perceived as an introduction to the cluster 16.1–9 that defines the questions the whole cluster is addressing. This understanding is strengthened by 16.9 (the last verse before the king-sayings), which not only corresponds to 16.1, but also contains allusions to all of the first three verses in ch. 16. This suggests that the compiler saw those three verses as one unit.24 Consequently, it is defendable to enquire only about the meaning of this particular subsection of the whole cluster.

I begin with some verse-by-verse comments. Although there will be an emphasis on the possible connections between the verses already in these investigations, readings of Prov. 16.1–3 as a whole will be provided only after these initial observations.

disp-quote.p: To man belongs the preparation of heart but the answer of tongue is from the Lord.

sec.title: The Lord Provides the Words
sec.p: One possible understanding of the verse is that although human beings prepare themselves to reply to certain situations/questions, the actual words are provided by God.25 In other words, God decides what one says and not the speaker him- or herself—a striking declaration of God's rule.

sec.title: The Lord Provides the Right Words
sec.p: Another possible interpretation is that the ‘answer’ does not refer to any answer, including potentially inappropriate words, but to the right answer.26 That is, the emphasis is not on divine determination of speech as such, but on the limitations of human efforts in guaranteeing success.

The ambiguity of interpretation does not affect the verse's core meaning. Both versions express the contrast between human and divine agency, and both emphasize the decisive role of God. Nonetheless, the second version, which teaches that human preparation without divine inspiration cannot guarantee success, might have a slightly less deterministic flavour, as it leaves open the possibility that however powerless human planning is, it is still needed.

It is hard to decide between these interpretations. If one takes Prov. 16.1 on its own, then the balance is towards the former interpretation, as the verse does not mention explicitly that it refers to ‘right’ words. However, taking the context into consideration, the balance shifts to the latter interpretation, as the parallel verse of 16.9 seems to refer to the theme of success, and not much earlier, 15.23 also speaks about finding the right words for the right moment.27

sec.title: The Lord Replies to Human Plans/Preparation
sec.p: A third possible interpretation also deserves our attention. Augustine understood 16.1b as referring not to human speech but to divine answer: ‘… man prepares his heart… But in the answer of the tongue—that is, in that which the divine tongue answers to the prepared heart—man has no part, but the whole is from the Lord God'.28 Thus the meaning would be: humans prepare their hearts, but—and this is the really decisive action—God reacts (answers) to this preparation.29
Examining only the exegetical grounds of these three possible interpretations, the first two options might seem preferable to this third one:

list-item.p: ‭הנעמ‬ is used twice in the previous chapter for human and not for divine answer (15.1, 23).

If ‘answer of the tongue’ is about human speech, then the verse not only contrasts human beings with God, but it also contains a nice contrast between inner preparation (heart) and outer expression (tongue). Such an elegant symmetry would also speak for the first two readings.

The word ‭ןושל‬ (‘tongue’) in itself suggests human speech. Despite all of its anthropomorphism, the Bible rarely mentions the tongue of Yahweh, so it is a moot point why the author would have chosen this particular word to refer to Yahweh's utterance when it is customarily connected to human speech.

sec.p: However, although these exegetical objections are not entirely without weight, they are not decisive either. There is no reason why ‭הנעמ‬ could not have a different subject in 16.1 than in 15.1 and 15.23. It is true that the ‘God answers to human preparation’ interpretation loses the ‘inner preparation/outer expression’ contrast, but it makes the human/divine contrast even stronger. Finally, even if the tongue of the Lord is very rarely mentioned, it is spoken of at least once outside Prov. 16.1, namely in Isa. 30.27.30

Moreover, some of these objections can be disarmed if Augustine's understanding is slightly modified. If one takes ‘answer of tongue’ in v. 1b not as a subjective genitive but as an objective genitive, then it would not refer to an answer uttered by God's tongue but to God's answer to the human tongue. Thus 16.1 would mean: humans plan/prepare to speak, then they speak, and then God replies to their speech.31

Consequently, although this third interpretation might seem a bit eccentric at first sight, it cannot be ruled out either. What is more, it also has a possible advantage: it fits the context of the following verse especially smoothly.

sec.title: b. 16.2

disp-quote.p: ‭הוהי תוחוך ןכתו וינעב ןו שיא יכךך לכ‬
All the ways of a man are pure in his eyes but the Lord examines spirits.

sec.p: Just like the previous verse, 16.2 depicts the contrast between human limitations and divine power. Because of this continuity of thought the reader is tempted to construct a precise logical connection between the verses. Various such logical connections can be imagined.

16.2 would be an especially coherent continuation of 16.1 if one understood v. 1b according to the (revised) Augustinian interpretation. A possible reading would then be: ‘Humans prepare their hearts and speak accordingly, but it is God's response to this human speech that matters (16.1), since it is God and not the humans themselves who can truly judge how successful their self-preparation was (16.2)'. But other readings with slightly different emphases are also possible. For example: ‘One can be certain of the correctness of God's response (mentioned in 16.1b) because God is able to judge humans better than they can judge themselves (16.2)'.32

If 16.1 is understood to be about God providing the (right) human response to questions/problems, then the logical connection with 16.2 might seem less obvious. Nevertheless, it is still possible to construct such connections. For example, if the reader takes into account the unspecified nature of the expression ‘preparation of heart’ in 16.1a, then this allows the possibility that the self-preparation in v. 1 goes beyond simple planning, and includes some sort of self-assessment. If this is so, then the theme of this self-preparation aligns well with 16.2, which speaks about human self-evaluation. So the reader could, for example, understand these verses together as saying that ‘no matter how hard one prepares oneself, it is only God who can control human reactions (16.1), as humans cannot even judge themselves properly (16.2)'.

disp-quote.p: Entrust your deeds to the Lord and your plans will be established.

sec.title: How to Be Successful?
sec.p: In v. 3 the interpreter faces many decisions that lead to different understandings of the text. Let us begin at the middle of the verse because much depends on how one understands the word ‭זוכ‬. ‭זוכ‬ in niphal means ‘to be established'.33 This expression can mean ‘to be realized’ or ‘to come true’, especially when it is applied to words like ‘plan’, ‘scheme’, and ‘desire'.34 Another possibility is that it means ‘to be made long-lasting’, as explained by Clifford: ‘one may finish a task but must entrust it to Yahweh in order for it to endure'.35 It is not necessary, however, to choose between these two understandings of ‘establish'. When the Bible promises a (would-be) king that his throne will be established, then it can mean both that his rulership will be realized, and also that it will be long-lasting (1 Sam. 20.31; 1 Kgs 2.45–46; 1 Chron. 17.14, 24; Prov. 29.14; etc.). To include both of these possible connotations we could simply say that ‭ןוכ‬, in relation to plans, means ‘to succeed'. So according to this reading, the verse answers the question, ‘How can one be successful?’

sec.title: How to Be Ready?
sec.p: However, ‘to succeed’ is not the only possible meaning of ‭ןוכ‬ niphal. In other places it often means ‘to be ready’ or ‘to be prepared’ for something. For example, Moses had to prepare the people of Israel for meeting God: ‘“Be prepared (‭םינכנ ויהו‬) for the third day because on the third day the Lord will come down”…and he said to the people, “Be prepared (‭םינכנ ויה‬) for the third day, do not approach a woman”’ (Exod. 19.11a, 15). God also commanded Moses himself to get prepared for meeting him: ‘be ready (‭ןוכנ היהו‬) by morning, and come up in the morning to Mount Sinai’ (Exod. 34.2a).36

Since ‭ןוכ‬ in niphal also often means ‘to be steadfast’ or ‘to be loyal’, as describing one's relationship to God (Pss 51.12 [et 10]; 57.8 [7]; 78.37; 108.2 [1]; 112.7; 119.5), many ancient and medieval interpreters understood ‘readiness’ not only in the sense of physical readiness but also in the sense of spiritual readiness. The idea of this ready, prepared heart has been one of the key concepts of Jewish spiritual teaching, Fishbane explains:

disp-quote.p: Who would suppose that Moses's charge to the people to ‘be ready’ and ‘prepared'… for the divine advent on Sinai… was only a physical separation from ordinary acts, and did not also include a spiritual sanctification as well…? Similarly, Moses himself was told to ‘be ready’ and ‘prepared’ (nakhon) for the moment of his personal ascent up the mountain… This certainly does not refer to the physical preparations themselves, which precede this command, but is an exhortation to spiritual exercises and alertness to the moment to come, as the medieval masters rightly perceived.
The cultivation of readiness begins in the heart, as the locus of inner balance … It longs for a healing beyond oneself; it longs for God to heal the fractured self and help guide it…

To live in this way is to cultivate naḥhat ruaḥh, a settled and balanced comportment of one's spirit and breath. With respect to God… this involves a ‘quietude of spirit'… and with respect to humankind…this involves a ‘pleasantness of being'.37

sec.p: Thus, once again, the interpreter is faced with a choice. Besides understanding 16.3 as speaking about the success of plans, grammatically and semantically it is also possible to understand it as about ‘one's thoughts being made ready/prepared'. Although this latter interpretation apparently has not occurred to modern interpreters, Matthew Henry (1662–1714) delineated this verse according to these lines:

disp-quote.p: It is a very desirable thing to have our thoughts established, and not tossed, and put into a hurry, by disquieting cares and fears,—to go on in an even steady course of honesty and piety, not disturbed, or put out of frame, by any event or change,—to be satisfied that all shall work for good and issue well at last, and therefore to be always easy and sedate.38

sec.p: Jerome also seems to understand the verse this way: ‘And so it is written, “Make my way right before Thy face”, so that what is right to Thee may seem also right to me. Solomon says the same—“Commit thy works unto the Lord, and thy thoughts shall be established”’.39

Although I am not aware of any recent commentaries that have picked up this ‘spiritual readiness’ interpretation, and as such it can appear rather unconventional to contemporary scholars, in my view it is not easy to decide between this and the above-explained ‘success’ interpretation. It is true that in the few other cases when ‭הבשחמ‬ occurs together with ‭ןוכ‬ in niphal (Prov. 20.18; 1QH 12.13), ‘success’ seems to be the meaning. However, these few cases do not provide enough material to rule out with certainty that the verse promises spiritual readiness. This latter option is especially tempting because it would fit the context of the previous verses that speak about preparing the heart (16.1) and the difficulty of judging one's own cleanness (16.2).

sec.title: Telling Our Deeds/Plans to the Lord
sec.p: Regardless of whether it is success or spiritual readiness that 16.3b promises, the same question might arise in the reader: What is the prerequisite of this desirable promise? The first word of the verse answers this question when it encourages the reader to ‭לג‬ his/her deeds to the Lord. However, once again, ‭לג‬ can mean two different things. It either means ‘entrust’ (literally ‘roll onto’) or ‘reveal'. The mt has ‭לג‬, meaning ‘roll onto'.40 The Syriac, Targum, and Vulgate read ‭לג‬, meaning ‘reveal'.41

The majority of scholars consider ‘entrust’ the better reading,42 but the issue is more ambiguous than it might seem at first sight. Waltke, summarizing the arguments for ‘entrust’, argues that Ps. 37.5a has the unmistakable plene ‭לוג‬ (‘entrust’) in an almost identical half-verse; furthermore, ‭הלג‬, from which ‭לג‬ (‘reveal’) is derived, never occurs with ‭לא‬ in qal.43 However, neither of these arguments is decisive. In Ps. 37.5 we have the same ambiguity, since the lxx, Vulgate, and Syriac read ‭לג‬.44 Furthermore, ‭הלג‬ qal does occur with ‭לא‬ at least once (Amos 3.7), not to mention the many non-qal occurrences with ‭לא‬ (Gen. 35.7; 1 Sam. 3.7; 14.8, 11; etc.).45

If the interpreter opts for ‘reveal’, then 16.3a can refer to telling God one's plans or confessing one's deeds to God.46 This understanding of v. 3a could create an interesting resonance with the previous verses. 16.1 and 16.3 could be connected by paraphrasing them as ‘Instead of trying to prepare yourself for successful speech (16.1), you should speak openly to God and then he will provide you success (16.3)'. Or, pressing the theme of spiritual preparation instead of success: ‘Instead of trying to prepare yourself for speech (16.1)—which is impossible as you cannot even know whether you are spiritually clean or not (16.2)—you should confess everything to God honestly and then he will prepare your thoughts (16.3)'.

sec.title: Entrusting Our Plans to the Lord
sec.p: However, let us turn back to the majority view: what exactly would ‘entrust your deeds to the Lord’ mean? Waltke helpfully explains it as describing a peaceful, contented mentality that is the opposite of anxious attempts to control everything.47 We should probably also add that ‘entrusting deeds to the Lord’ does not describe a fatalistic passivity that teaches that ‘everything is in God's hands, so it is better to give up all plans and actions and just accept bluntly whatever comes'. A look at those verses that are often compared to Prov. 16.3 (i.e. Pss. 22.9; 37.5; 55.23; 90.17; Prov. 3.5–6; Sir. 7.17 [Hebrew text of MS A]; 1 Pet. 5.7)48 reveals that the intended effect of this terminology is that the reader should continue his ethical/law-obeying behaviour and trust that God will provide success at the end—even if such ethical behaviour seems ineffective, and unethical means seem to have higher potential to achieve the desired results. This understanding is supported by the fact that the contexts of almost all of the parallel texts imply a contrast between the evil person and the humble/ethical person.49 They encourage the reader not to be proud, not to envy the evil, and not to be angry because of the success of the evil, but instead to wait for the Lord's rescue. Thus, the idea of ‘entrusting to the Lord’ is not as much an encouragement for passivity as it is an encouragement for a certain type of activity: act ethically, and wait and see that the Lord will respond to such actions by providing success. As Fox writes, ‘Entrust…does not mean merely planning and then hoping for the best. It means to make one's plans congruent with God's will.'50

To summarize my observations of 16.3, the analysis of the two verbs in it has led to four possible readings. Besides the most common ‘Entrust [i.e. be ethical, do not be anxious] your deeds to the Lord and your plans will be successful', it is possible to understand the verse as referring to spiritual preparation: ‘Entrust your deeds to the Lord and your thoughts will be prepared'. In both cases it is possible that the prerequisite of success/spiritual readiness is not entrusting the deeds to God, but openly revealing the (planned or committed) deeds to him.51

sec.title: 3. Variations on One Text
sec.p: It is time to take one step back from these remarks on the individual verses and to consider how these variant readings affect a coherent interpretation of the whole section of Prov. 16.1–3. The following table summarizes the alternative translations of the text mentioned so far:

If a reader wishes to read the verses together, then it is almost inevitable that some additional themes besides the broad topic of divine power and human limitations will emerge. Whether that is the topic of ‘success’ or ‘spiritual cleanness’ or something else depends on how one understands the individual verses and connects them to each other. I offer here three possible readings. Each time I provide a paraphrase which is hopefully self-explanatory enough, and a translation that could support the given paraphrase.

tr.td: Human beings work on their own spiritual preparation. However, they are unable even to evaluate their own state of spiritual readiness because it is only the Lord who can evaluate such things. So, how can someone be ready spiritually? The secret is: one must not try to control everything by using any means (even unethical ones), but one has to trust in the Lord's power and beneficial attention. Then one will be spiritually prepared.
To man belongs the preparation of the heart but the reply to this preparation comes from the Lord.
All the ways of a man are pure in his eyes but the Lord examines spirits.
Entrust your deeds to the Lord and your thoughts will be prepared.

caption.p: Reading 2. The Role of Speech in Spiritual Readiness

tr.td: Humans try to prepare their attitudes for speaking well but right speech comes from God. This is so because human self-preparation is in a sense impossible since they cannot judge themselves impartially. So, instead of trying to control their speech, they should speak to God openly and reveal their thoughts to him. This is what leads to preparedness, and not trying to prepare themselves on their own.
To man belongs the preparation of the heart but right speech is from the Lord.
All the ways of a man are pure in his eyes but the Lord examines spirits.
Reveal your deeds to the Lord and your thoughts will be prepared.

Human beings plan their actions because they want to be successful. However, success is rooted in the Lord's decision and not in human preparation. The Lord knows what the true intentions of people are and he acts according to this knowledge. So, instead of striving for success, people should leave that to the Lord and refrain from using whatever (even unethical) means in order to achieve their aims. Paradoxically, when someone is willing to let success go, then God will provide success.
To man belongs the plans of the heart but the reply to this planning comes from the Lord.
All the ways of a man are pure in his eyes but the Lord examines spirits.
Entrust your deeds to the Lord and your plans will be successful.

sec.p: It could be argued that these paraphrases go well beyond what the text actually says. They presuppose logical relationships between the verses that are not mentioned explicitly by the text, and they equate expressions of the text that do not necessarily speak about the same subject. However, I argued above that this kind of ‘gap-filling’ matches the writing-method of the authors and it is also encouraged by the many obvious gaps in the text. Consequently, I would contend that all three of these interpretations (and many others) can be taken as feasible explanations of the text.

The fact that the gaps in a text can be filled in many ways does not mean that the interpretation is without control. There are important ‘checks’ on a reading. First, even though I presented different readings with different emphases, I still tried to produce readings that are allowed by the grammar of the text and that remain within the semantic range of its words. Furthermore, I also tried to produce interpretations that do not contradict the thought-world of the ‘framework’ of Proverbs (chs. 1–9 and 30–31) and that fit smoothly the harmonious net of propositions in Proverbs 10–29.52

It not only follows from this latter ‘contextual check’ that some readings might be ruled out by it. Another consequence is that most of the possible readings do not contradict each other, since all of them fit the same context harmoniously. In other words, they are complementary and not contradictory. To highlight this phenomenon we can take the example of the two readings that concentrate on success and on spiritual readiness. Proverbs as a book often writes about God's retribution and suggests that he provides success to those who walk his way, that is, to those who are attuned to him and his way of action.53 Consequently, according to Proverbs, the way to success is a God-fearing, ethical, clean life. Although the above-constructed Reading 1 (spiritual readiness) and Reading 3 (success) seem to be quite different, both of them grasp a part of the broader context of Proverbs and consequently they can be understood as complementing each other.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: I have argued that the diverse links between the verses of sayings-clusters in Proverbs 10–29 encourage the reader to construe unified teachings for the clusters. In other words, the reader is invited to interpret individual verses in their literary context. I tentatively suggested that this reading method might be in accordance with the writing method of the authors/editors: the sequence of proverbs probably mirrors the associative processes of the author/editor, as their choice of a proverb was likely influenced by their pondering on the previous proverbs in the same cluster. Similarly, the reader is invited into an associative reading.

However, I have also argued that it is not the task of the reader to ‘reconstruct’ what went on in the mind of the author/editor when they were compiling a cluster. The weak nature of the links between the verses suggests that there is no secret message hidden in their sequence. The task of the reader is not discovering an encoded message, but exploiting the surplus of meaning inherent in the ambiguous connections between the verses and the logical gaps between them. Such a reading can result in a richer reading experience than just concentrating on the individual verses in isolation.

I have tried to show the above on the example of Prov. 16.1–3. I have argued that if these verses are read together, certain themes can emerge in a more multifaceted way than if the individual verses were read only on their own. However, I have also insisted that more than one reading is possible: in my three examples the section is either on spiritual preparation, on the importance of confessing to the Lord in order to be (spiritually) prepared for right speech, or on success. Nevertheless, the diversity of possible readings does not mean that they are arbitrary. Good readings pay close attention to the text and they are in harmony with the framework of the book and with the network of the sayings in Proverbs 10–29.

Thus, in the particular case of Proverbs 10–29, the biblical text invites even the academic reader to a pondering, careful, but at the same time explicitly playful, reading. Scholars should not shy away from using their imagination, and should exploit the ambiguities of the text in order to offer creative constructions of the meaning of sayings-clusters in Proverbs.

The word ‘cluster’ is ill-defined, and as such it requires some clarification. Michael V. Fox, speaking about ‘thematic clusters’, defines them as ‘groups of at least two sayings that speak on the same topic or share catchwords’ (Fox, Proverbs 10–31, p. 478). The main interest of my investigation is more general than what this ‘narrow’ definition would allow: if one finds a group of at least two sayings, the vast majority of which are connected to each other either thematically or by literary devices, how should this influence the reader's interpretation of the text?

Thus, my definition of ‘cluster’ is broader than Fox's in two significant ways: first, I consider not only thematic but also literary connections (alliteration between key expressions in neighbouring verses, linkage by an ordered sequence of initial letters, etc.); second, I accept a group of sayings as a cluster even if not all but only a clear majority of the verses are connected. The reading which understands the beginning of 16.3 as confessing one's deeds to the Lord does not fit easily the thought-world of Prov. 1–29 as we hardly read about prayer in it. Nonetheless, even if it stands on its own in these parts of Proverbs, it is not contradicted by them; and we do read about prayer in Agur's speech in 30.1–9. That speech is undoubtedly a later addition to the book; nevertheless, if one reads Prov. 16.3 in its canonical context, then Prov. 30.7–9 is a neat parallel for it with many conceptual similarities. Though the interpretation of Agur's speech is highly debated, it can be read as an expression of the attitude recommended in Prov. 16.3: confessing one's deeds/ thoughts to God, leaving everything onto him, and waiting for him to establish one's steps.
